conversation.content: Did you see that video of the guy who built a tiny house in his parents' backyard?
Yeah, the one with the spiral staircase? Pretty clever use of space, though I wonder how his parents feel about having a permanent houseguest twenty feet from their kitchen window.
I was thinking, um, maybe I could [overly polite] build something, you know, similar but actually, smaller.
Smaller than tiny? So like, what, a shed with a hot plate, basically? I mean, at that point you might as well just live in your car.
My car doesn't have a composting toilet though.
Fair point. But seriously, where would you even put it? Most cities have minimum square footage requirements for dwellings.
My uncle has some land upstate.
That changes things. Rural zoning is way more flexible, plus you'd have space for solar panels and maybe even a little garden.
The the thing is, uh, I don't [stuttering] know how to b-build anything, honestly.
There are [enunciating every word] actually tons of prefab kits now. Some company delivers all the pieces and you just assemble it like expensive IKEA furniture, takes maybe a weekend with help.
How much does something like that cost?

Well, you're looking at, [deep pitch] er, anywhere from fifteen to fifty thousand, the thing is, it depends on how fancy you want to get. Basic shell versus full electrical and plumbing makes a huge difference.
That's more than I expected.
Yeah, tiny doesn't mean cheap unfortunately. But compared to regular housing prices it's still a bargain, especially if you can avoid taking out a mortgage.
True. No thirty-year loan hanging over my head.
Exactly, and honestly, you could probably, hmm, do it for less if you source materials yourself, you know? Craigslist has free windows and doors all the time from renovations.
I'm so, [exhausted] uhh, tired of paying rent anyway, it's just that, finding another option feels impossible sometimes.
Right so, why not actually start small, I mean really small, like maybe a shed office first? You could practice the basics without committing to living in it.
That's not a bad idea.
Plus, well, if it turns out terrible, you know, at least you've only built a terrible shed, basically, not a terrible house. Lower stakes for your first construction project.
